name: Fight Colorectal Cancer
mission: We raise our voice to empower and activate a community of patients, fighters and champions to push for better policies and to support research, educatio...
theoryOfChange: Fight Colorectal Cancer has a published strategic framework called "Path to a Cure," which is described as a "visionary roadmap for the future of colorectal cancer research" aimed at accelerating progress across all stages of the disease continuum. This framework includes an annual "Progress Report" that evaluates indicators, highlights achievements, and identifies areas needing further investment. Additionally, the charity has the "Colorectal Cancer Care Initiative (CRCCI)," which is a "data-driven roadmap" that sets "clear, actionable goals for CRC screening and care" and outlines "five targets to help achieve two key goals: Timely Colorectal Cancer Screening and Accurate, Informative Diagnosis and Timely Treatment Initiation." The CRCCI's "Colorectal Cancer Care Report" is a tool designed to "leverage data to measure progress, allocate resources, and improve outcomes."

alignment.rationale: Alignment 26/50: LOW Muslim donor fit, global health cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data; high program ratio (≥85%) suggests efficient delivery

score_details.score_summary: Fight Colorectal Cancer earns 57/100 due to good impact and moderate alignment.

all_citations.claim: Fight Colorectal Cancer focuses on advocacy, research, and education with high fundraising efficiency.
The organization reported total revenue of $3,060,301, a program expense ratio of 85.2%, and 12.0 months of working capital.
Audited financials confirm the organization's revenue and expense distribution for its mission-driven programs.
Recent financial records show continued investment in research and public policy initiatives.
The organization accepts general charitable donations (sadaqah) to support its mission of empowering patients and survivors.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization demonstrates strong financial health and efficiency in its operations, though its specialized focus on advocacy and policy results in a moderate alignment for general donors seeking direct humanitarian impact.
areas_for_improvement: Limited direct alignment with specific Muslim donor preferences or religious giving frameworks
Focus is primarily on capacity building and advocacy rather than direct clinical service delivery

dimension_explanations.alignment: The alignment score of 26/50 reflects a high cause urgency regarding global health, yet a lower specific fit for traditional Muslim donor priorities [1][8]. While the organization is a reputable recipient for sadaqah, it lacks specific features or programming tailored to the Muslim community's charitable traditions [8].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization shows a moderate impact score of 31/50, reflecting its focus on capacity building and policy change rather than direct patient treatment [1][4]. With a total revenue of $3,060,301 and a program expense ratio of 85.2%, it maintains high financial transparency and directs significant resources toward its advocacy and research programs [2][3].

baseline_narrative.headline: Fight Colorectal Cancer empowers a national community of survivors and advocates to advance medical research and public policy.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 85.2%, indicating the majority of funds directly support core missions [2]
Exceptional fundraising efficiency, spending only $0.07 to raise every $1 in donations [1]
Strong liquidity with 12.0 months of working capital available to sustain operations [2]
baseline_narrative.summary: Fight Colorectal Cancer is a non-profit organization dedicated to activating a community of patients and champions to push for better policies and support colorectal cancer research and education [1][2]. The organization operates through three primary pillars: patient education, public awareness, and legislative advocacy [1][8].

alignment.explanation: While the cause of global health is urgent, the organization is <cite id="1">Sadaqah-eligible only</cite> and lacks specific religious or cultural tailoring for Muslim donors.
alignment.improvement: Alignment could be improved by <cite id="1">developing outreach programs</cite> that address the specific health needs or disparities within Muslim communities in the US.

credibility.explanation: Donors can trust this charity due to its <cite id="11">20/20 compliance with BBB standards</cite> and its <cite id="4">audited financial statements</cite> which confirm transparent reporting.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility further, the charity could publish more detailed <cite id="1">impact metrics and beneficiary data</cite> to complement its financial transparency.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="4">83.4% program ratio</cite> and a <cite id="1">strong theory of change</cite> focused on capacity building and policy influence.
impact.improvement: Impact measurement would benefit from <cite id="1">tracking and reporting specific beneficiary counts</cite> to enable a more granular cost-effectiveness analysis.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize systemic change through policy advocacy and medical research rather than direct clinical aid.
donor_motivations: Want to support long-term cancer research and policy shifts
Value high financial efficiency and low overhead costs
Prefer supporting established US-based health advocacy
Seek organizations with the highest transparency ratings
giving_considerations: Donations support advocacy and education, not direct patient treatment
Impact is measured through policy wins and research milestones
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking to fulfill zakat obligations or those who prefer funding direct medical procedures for individuals.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade B reflects <cite id="1">verified evidence and outcomes</cite> through Candid, though it lacks independent RCT-level evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: Fight CRC uses a <cite id="1">strong theory of change</cite> that leverages patient advocacy to influence federal research funding and healthcare policy.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that advocacy efforts translate into actual policy changes and research advancements.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With a <cite id="2">$3.1M revenue base</cite> and a growing advocacy mandate, the organization has significant capacity to scale its research grants.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its <cite id="1">exceptionally low fundraising costs of $0.07 per dollar</cite> compared to peers.

strengths.detail: The organization maintains a <cite id="4">program expense ratio of 85.2%</cite>, ensuring that the vast majority of donor funds support advocacy and education.
Fight CRC spends only <cite id="1">$0.07 to raise every $1</cite> in donations, significantly outperforming industry benchmarks for efficiency.
The charity maintains <cite id="1">12.0 months of working capital</cite>, providing a strong safety net for long-term advocacy campaigns.

strengths_deep_dive: Fight CRC's operational excellence is evidenced by its <cite id="1">Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>, the highest level of disclosure available. Their financial management is characterized by a <cite id="2">3-year revenue CAGR of 10.9%</cite>, showing steady growth even in a competitive health advocacy landscape. Furthermore, the organization meets <cite id="11">all 20 BBB Wise Giving Alliance Standards</cite> for Charity Accountability, confirming rigorous oversight of its <cite id="2">9-member independent board</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: Fight Colorectal Cancer (Fight CRC) serves as a national advocacy and research powerhouse dedicated to empowering survivors and advancing medical policy. The organization reported <cite id="2">$3,060,301 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 fiscal year, maintaining a lean operational model where <cite id="4">83.4% of expenses are directed to programs</cite>. Their work is structured around three strategic pillars: <cite id="1">advocacy, research, and patient education</cite>, which aim to reduce the burden of colorectal cancer through systemic change. By training survivors through the <cite id="1">Research Advocacy Training & Support (RATS) Program</cite>, the charity ensures that the patient voice is central to clinical trial design and federal funding decisions. Financially, the organization demonstrates high stability, holding <cite id="1">12.0 months of working capital</cite> in working capital. This liquidity, combined with an <cite id="1">exceptional fundraising efficiency of $0.07</cite> spent for every dollar raised, positions Fight CRC as a highly efficient vehicle for health-focused philanthropy. While the organization does not provide direct clinical care, it creates impact through <cite id="2">$27,600 in strategic grants</cite> to partners like the Nebraska Cancer Coalition and by influencing national screening policies.
